sect1.title: OpenBSD and FreeBSD
sect1.para: Firewall Builder supports configuring "pf", "ipfilter" and "ipfw" rules for OpenBSD and FreeBSD systems.

sect2.title: PF
sect2.para: To create a new "pf" firewall select the PF platform option on the first page of the New Firewall Wizard. You must also choose whether the firewall will be running on OpenBSD (default) or FreeBSD.

sect3.title: FreeBSD
sect3.para: Starting in Firewall Builder V4.2 there are two supported modes for generating "pf" firewall configurations on FreeBSD systems.

orderedlist.listitem: Standard Mode - in this case Firewall Builder generates both a pf.conf style configuration file and a .fw activation script.
rc.conf Mode - in this case Firewall Builder generates both a pf.conf style configuration file and a rc.conf.local style configuration file.

note.para: By default file names use the name of the firewall object as the base of the filename. For example, a firewall named "guardian" would generate files called guardian.conf (pf.conf style commands) and guardian.fw (bash shell activation script OR rc.conf.local style settings).
Users can override the default file names by changing the settings in the Firewall Settings on the Compiler tab.

sect3.para: In this mode Firewall Builder generates a firewall.conf file that uses the same style as pf.conf. By default Firewall Builder will install this file in /etc. You can update the installation location by clicking on the Installer tab in the Firewall Settings. The first entry is directory location on the firewall.

Firewall Builder will also generate a firewall.fw file when it is configured in Standard mode. This is a bash shell script file that will set interface IP addresses, create static routes, etc. if these options have been selected in Firewall Settings.
This is the default mode and you don't need to change any settings to use Firewall Builder in this mode with your PF firewall running on FreeBSD.

To switch from Standard Mode to rc.conf mode open the Firewall Settings window. Click on the tab labeled Script. If your Host OS is set to FreeBSD you will see two radial buttons at the top of the window to set the initialization mode. Select the radial next to the "file in rc.conf format".
In this mode the firewall.conf file that gets generated is the same as the firewall.conf file that gets generated in the Standard Mode.
Instead of a bash shell script in this mode the initialization file, firewall.fw, will be in rc.conf settings format as shown below.

sect2.para: For ipfilter Firewall Builder generates three files: the firewall-ipf.conf file with filter rules, firewall-nat.conf file with NAT rules and firewall.fw with policy activation script.
For ipfw a single script firewall.fw is generated, this script does all the prepararory work and then loads ipfw rules.

sect1.para: By default, generated scripts are installed in the /etc/fw/ directory on the firewall and the work of making sure they are executed on system start-up is left for the administrator. See for some recommended ways to do this.
